items.name: addressing-law-no-2014-78.md
items.title: Addressing (By-law No. 2014–78) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This by-law regulates the naming of private roads and highways and the numbering of buildings and lots, detailing application processes, administrative responsibilities, public notification, requirements for civic number and street name signs, agreements for private roads, enforcement, penalties, and associated fees.

items.name: amended-heritage-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2024-176.md
items.title: Amended Heritage Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2024-176) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The Amended Heritage Community Improvement Plan encourages the restoration and rehabilitation of designated heritage buildings by offering a financial incentive in the form of a Tax Increment Equivalent Grant, funded by a portion of the resulting increase in municipal property taxes, to conserve heritage properties, integrate them into developments, and increase housing units.

items.name: amended-integrated-orleans-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2024-173.md
items.title: Amended Integrated Orléans Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2024-173) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text describes the adoption of a new Integrated Community Improvement Plan for the Orléans area, replacing previous plans, which aims to stimulate private sector investment in redevelopment through financial incentives like Tax Increment Equivalent Grants to encourage revitalization, job creation, mixed-use development, and improved aesthetics, particularly leveraging opportunities from transit expansion, with specific programs targeting the St. Joseph Boulevard Main Street, employment creation, and pedestrian-friendly streets, and is intended to operate for 10 years with annual monitoring.

items.name: amended-montreal-road-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2024-174.md
items.title: Amended Montreal Road Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2024-174) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: An Amended Community Improvement Plan for the Montreal Road area provides a financial incentive program, primarily a Tax Increment Equivalent Grant (TIEG), to stimulate private sector investment, urban renewal, and property upgrades by reimbursing eligible property owners a portion of the municipal tax increase resulting from development and redevelopment projects, with supplementary benefits for projects supporting cultural activities, artists, or social enterprises in a specific district, aiming to revitalize the area, improve its appearance, encourage density, support arts, culture, and social enterprises, and increase employment.

items.name: animal-care-and-control-law-no-2003-077.md
items.title: Animal Care and Control (By-law No. 2003-077) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text outlines regulations for animal care and control including mandatory registration and identification tags for cats and dogs, limits on the number of pets allowed per household, requirements for leashing dogs and removing animal waste, rules regarding vicious dogs and impoundment procedures, mandates for rabies immunization and quarantine, restrictions on keeping livestock, pigeons, and rabbits in residential areas, a list of prohibited animals, and general standards for animal welfare and noise control.

items.name: appendix-b-amendment-schedule-zoning-law-and-interim-control-laws-law-no-2022-232.md
items.title: Appendix B - Amendment Schedule to the Zoning By-law and Interim Control By-laws (By-law No. 2022-232) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This appendix provides a regularly updated list of amendments to the zoning regulation, sorted by number from most recent, including details on affected properties, enactment dates with links to council meeting documents, status (including appeal information), and notes that the appendix is for reference while amendments are integrated into the main regulation text once fully in effect.

items.name: atv-orv-and-snowmobile-law-no-2019-421.md
items.title: ATV, ORV and Snowmobile (By-law No. 2019-421) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document regulates the operation of All-Terrain Vehicles, Multi-Purpose Off-Highway Utility Vehicles, Recreational Off-Highway Vehicles, and Motorized Snow Vehicles, specifying designated highways and unopened road allowances where their use is permitted, outlining procedures for establishing new routes, setting rules for speed, hours of operation, required club membership, vehicle modifications, seasonal restrictions, and detailing enforcement provisions.

items.name: auditor-general-law-no-2021-5.md
items.title: Auditor General (By-law No. 2021-5) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes the position of Auditor General, detailing the process for appointment by Council including qualification requirements, ensuring independence and direct reporting to Council, defining responsibilities such as conducting financial, compliance, and performance audits of municipal entities and grant recipients, investigating fraud and waste, granting necessary access to information and records, requiring an annual audit plan approved by Council, outlining reporting procedures, authorizing the establishment and management of the Auditor General's office and budget, and providing for confidentiality and immunity from testimony.

items.name: bilingualism-law-no-2001-170.md
items.title: Bilingualism (By-law No. 2001-170) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text establishes the right of citizens to communicate and receive services in both English and French, in accordance with a specific policy, while ensuring that the implementation of this bilingualism policy does not result in employee job loss and is carried out in co-operation and consultation with collective bargaining groups.

items.name: board-law-no-2010-211.md
items.title: Board Up (By-law No. 2010-211) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulations require owners of vacant or damaged buildings with accessible openings to board them up, and if the owner fails to comply after receiving notice, the authority may perform the work at the owner's expense, adding the costs to the property's tax roll, with non-compliance being an offence.

items.name: boards-management-business-improvement-areas-law-no-2021-255.md
items.title: Boards of Management for Business Improvement Areas (By-law No. 2021-255) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes standardized governance for boards managing improvement areas, detailing requirements for board composition, director appointment and removal, terms of office, roles and responsibilities including policy setting and financial management, officer duties, committee structure, the hiring and role of an executive director, accountability measures, confidentiality and conflict of interest rules, meeting procedures, annual reporting, membership eligibility, mandatory policies, record keeping, and the process for dissolution.

items.name: borrowing-upon-30-year-sinking-fund-debentures-law-no-2017-355.md
items.title: Borrowing upon 30 year sinking fund debentures (By-law No. 2017-355) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Authorization for borrowing $102,000,000.00 via 30-year sinking fund debentures maturing November 10, 2047 at 3.25% interest, designated as green debentures for transit capital work including vehicles and facilities, detailing terms for issuance, registration, transfer, and payment.

items.name: borrowing-upon-additional-sinking-fund-debentures-200000000-law-no-2019-272.md
items.title: Borrowing upon additional sinking fund debentures $200,000,000 (By-law No. 2019-272) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Authorization for borrowing $200,000,000.00 through the issue of additional 3.25% sinking fund debentures maturing November 10, 2047, as a re-opening of a previous issue under a Green Debenture Framework, towards the cost of certain capital works, including Light Rail Transit projects.

items.name: borrowing-upon-additional-sinking-fund-debentures-225000000-law-no-2021-359.md
items.title: Borrowing upon additional sinking fund debentures $225,000,000 (By-law No. 2021-359) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Authorization is granted by the enacting body for borrowing $225,000,000.00 via additional 2.50% sinking fund debentures due May 11, 2051, to fund a capital work, specifically transit projects under a green debenture framework, with principal and interest payments, including sinking fund contributions, to be raised through the general municipal levy.

items.name: borrowing-upon-sinking-fund-debentures-200000000-law-no-2022-166.md
items.title: Borrowing upon sinking fund debentures $200,000,000 (By-law No. 2022-166) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Authorization for borrowing $200,000,000.00 via sinking fund debentures to finance capital works, specifically Light Rail Transit Stage 2, consistent with a Green Debenture Framework, detailing the issuance of 30-year debentures maturing December 6, 2052, with a 4.10% annual interest rate paid semi-annually, requiring annual sinking fund contributions, and establishing procedures for their registration, transfer, and payment.

items.name: borrowing-upon-sinking-fund-debentures-300000000-law-no-2020-110.md
items.title: Borrowing upon sinking fund debentures $300,000,000 (By-law No. 2020-110) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Authorization is granted to borrow $300,000,000.00 via sinking fund debentures to fund a capital work, identified as the Light Rail Transit Stage 2 project, with the debentures dated May 11, 2020, maturing May 11, 2051, carrying a 2.50% annual interest rate payable semi-annually, requiring annual sinking fund deposits, initially issued as global registered certificates, and funded through the general municipal levy and other available sources.

items.name: building-law-no-2014-220.md
items.title: Building (By-law No. 2014-220) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document details the requirements and procedures for applications, permits, fees, submissions of plans and information, inspections, public safety measures, and handling of application and permit status concerning the construction, renovation, demolition, or change of use of buildings and designated structures.

items.name: city-manager-law-no-2025-68.md
items.title: City Manager (By-law No. 2025-68) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The position of City Manager is established as the Chief Administrative Officer responsible for the general control and management of affairs and administration, accountable to Council, with the appointment and dismissal process detailed, including delegation options and a two-thirds majority vote requirement for Council appointments.

items.name: clothing-donation-box-law-no-2023-425.md
items.title: Clothing Donation Box (By-law No. 2023–425) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text establishes regulations for clothing donation boxes, requiring permits for owners and operators, setting standards for location, maintenance, and information display, outlining enforcement procedures, penalties for violations, and detailing specific rules and an allocation process for placing boxes on public property.

items.name: code-conduct-members-council-law-no-2025-99.md
items.title: Code of Conduct for Members of Council (By-law No. 2025-99) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes standards of conduct for elected officials, covering areas such as integrity, confidentiality, meeting behaviour, non-discrimination, proper use of resources, interactions with staff, expenses, lobbying, gifts, and election-related activities, and outlines procedures for addressing complaints and imposing sanctions for non-compliance.

items.name: code-conduct-members-local-boards-law-no-2018-399.md
items.title: Code of Conduct for Members of Local Boards (By-law No. 2018-399) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document sets forth standards of conduct for individuals serving on local boards, addressing areas such as integrity, confidentiality, meeting decorum, respect for others and staff, proper use of influence and resources, acceptance of gifts, election-related activities, outside affiliations, and communications, and establishes a process for addressing alleged breaches through investigation by an Integrity Commissioner and potential imposition of sanctions.

items.name: code-conduct-public-members-built-heritage-committee-law-no-2025-77.md
items.title: Code of Conduct for Public Members of the Built Heritage Committee (By-law No. 2025-77) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This code of conduct for public members of the Built Heritage Committee sets standards for integrity, confidentiality, meeting conduct, non-discrimination, proper use of influence and resources, interaction with staff, conflict of interest, lobbying, and gifts, outlining compliance and complaint procedures managed by the Integrity Commissioner and replacing a prior code.

items.name: community-benefits-charge-law-law-no-2022-307.md
items.title: Community Benefits Charge By-law (By-law No. 2022-307) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: A Community Benefit Charge is imposed on development and redevelopment projects that are five or more storeys and add ten or more residential units, calculated as 4% of the land value, to fund capital costs for growth-related facilities and services, with provisions for exemptions, payment timing, land valuation, in-kind contributions, and a special account for collected funds.

items.name: community-safety-zone-law-no-2019-397.md
items.title: Community Safety Zone (By-law No. 2019-397) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text designates specific parts of roadways as community safety zones due to public safety concerns, establishing defined areas with associated speed limits.

items.name: compliance-reports-law-no-2003-069.md
items.title: Compliance Reports (By-law No. 2003-069) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Upon written request by an applicant, various compliance reports are available detailing information from records regarding building permits, work orders, violations, zoning conformity, pool enclosures, development agreements, and rooming house status, with specific fees applicable for each type of report including Summary, Zoning, Pool Enclosure, Agreement, Release of Agreement, and Rooming House reports.

items.name: contribution-rebate-program-law-no-2022-76.md
items.title: Contribution Rebate Program (By-law No. 2022-76) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes a Contribution Rebate Program authorizing payments to Ontario residents who contribute money of $25.01 or more to participating candidates for municipal council office, outlining eligibility rules, application processes, candidate requirements including financial reporting and audits, defining ineligible contributions (such as goods, services, or contributions to school board trustees/third parties), detailing how rebates are calculated with a general maximum of $75 per individual (or up to $900 for contributions to withdrawn candidates), setting conditions for rebate payment based on compliance and absence of election finance violations, and repealing previous program regulations.

items.name: delegation-authority-law-no-2025-69.md
items.title: Delegation of Authority (By-law No. 2025-69) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document details the delegation of authority from Council to various officers and staff, empowering them to manage operations, finances, services, infrastructure, planning, legal matters, and strategic initiatives, including specific powers for agreements, permits, property transactions, and personnel decisions.

items.name: demolition-control-law-no-2012-377.md
items.title: Demolition Control (By-law No. 2012-377) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Establishing control over the demolition of residential properties within a designated area by requiring permits, outlining exceptions and conditions for permit issuance, and specifying penalties for violations to maintain housing stock and neighbourhood integrity.

items.name: deputy-mayors-law-no-2023-11.md
items.title: Deputy Mayors (By-law No. 2023-11) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes rules for appointing members of council to act in place of the head of council when absent or the office is vacant, granting them the head of council's powers and duties, establishing scheduled appointments for Deputy Mayors, outlining procedures for amending the schedule and appointing alternative members if needed, and repealing a previous rule concerning such appointments, effective January 1, 2023.

items.name: discharge-firearms-law-no-2002-344.md
items.title: Discharge of Firearms (By-law No. 2002-344) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document regulates the discharge of firearms, specifying prohibited areas including shaded map zones, navigable waters, highways, public lands, and areas near places of worship, schools, public halls, subdivisions, and the Trans Canada Trail, while providing exceptions for longbows/crossbows in specific circumstances and exemptions for peace officers, animal control agents, farmers, authorized clubs/facilities, specific film/sport/training uses, and certain archery activities.

items.name: e-scooters-law-no-2020-174.md
items.title: E-scooters (By-law No. 2020 - 174) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes regulations for the operation and use of electric kick scooters, including definitions of the vehicle and related terms, specifying where they may and may not be operated such as on highways, sidewalks, trails, and parks, outlining rules for safe operation including age restrictions, helmet requirements, carrying passengers or cargo, required equipment like bells and lights, and maintaining safe distances, detailing parking regulations requiring use of designated facilities or specific areas within furniture zones, describing procedures for the removal, impounding, and disposal of improperly parked scooters along with associated fees, and setting out enforcement measures and penalties for contraventions, with these rules effective from June 24, 2020, until November 27, 2024.

items.name: encroachments-city-highways-law-no-2003-446.md
items.title: Encroachments on City Highways (By-law No. 2003-446) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes regulations for objects and structures placed on public roads and pathways, including definitions, permit requirements, application procedures, general rules, specific provisions for items like tourist information directories, waste receptacles, and customer service boxes, fee schedules, and enforcement measures.

items.name: fence-law-no-2003-462.md
items.title: Fence (By-law No. 2003-462) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text establishes rules for the construction, height limits, and upkeep of barriers used to define property boundaries, restrict access, or provide security, detailing requirements based on property type and location, including specific rules for visibility, materials, and condition, while also outlining exceptions and enforcement procedures.

items.name: film-law-law-no-2020-164.md
items.title: Film By-law (By-law No. 2020-164) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines the requirements for obtaining permits, establishing rules, and overseeing filming activities conducted on various types of property.

items.name: fire-routes-law-no-2003-499.md
items.title: Fire Routes (By-law No. 2003-499) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text designates specific fire routes, mandates property owners install and maintain authorized signs for these routes, prohibits stopping or parking on them except for emergency vehicles, details enforcement procedures including vehicle removal, specifies requirements for signs, repeals previous related regulations, and establishes penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: fireworks-law-no-2003-237.md
items.title: Fireworks (By-law No. 2003-237) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulations govern the sale and setting off of fireworks, prohibiting firecrackers and certain types, restricting consumer fireworks sales to specific holidays and the seven business days before, limiting consumer fireworks discharge to specific holidays and the day before and after, requiring permits for display and special effect fireworks with detailed application, insurance, and indemnification requirements, and allowing temporary prohibition of consumer fireworks discharge by the Fire Chief based on conditions.

items.name: graffiti-management-law-no-2008-01.md
items.title: Graffiti Management (By-law No. 2008-01) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The regulations prohibit placing graffiti on property, require owners to maintain property free of graffiti, outline enforcement procedures including notice and removal with cost recovery, specify offences and penalties, and exclude interior spaces and certain designated areas.

items.name: heat-law-no-2010-210.md
items.title: Heat (By-law No. 2010-210) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This regulation mandates that landlords maintain adequate heat in rented dwelling accommodations where heating is provided, specifying minimum temperatures of 16.67°C from 11 pm to 6 am and 20°C from 6 am to 11 pm, and establishes procedures for non-compliance including issuing notices, potential intervention by the Director with cost recovery, and penalties for violations.

items.name: idling-control-law-no-2024-437.md
items.title: Idling Control (By-law No. 2024-437) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This regulation establishes controls on vehicle idling by setting time limits for occupied and unoccupied vehicles that vary with temperature, lists exemptions for specific situations and vehicle types, details enforcement and penalties including fines for contraventions, repeals a prior regulation, and is designated the Idling Control Regulation, becoming effective January 1, 2025.

items.name: information-and-materials-planning-applications-law-no-2023-297.md
items.title: Information and Materials for Planning Applications (By-law No. 2023-297) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Outlines the information and materials required for submitting planning applications including Official Plan, Zoning, Subdivision, Condominium, Site Plan Control, and Boundary Expansion amendments, specifying a list of potential additional studies, plans, reports, and assessments that may be requested.

items.name: integrated-orleans-community-improvement-plan-law-no-2021-284.md
items.title: Integrated Orléans Community Improvement Plan (By-law No. 2021-284) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Designating a specific area as the Integrated Orléans Community Improvement Plan Project Area and repealing the previous St. Joseph Boulevard and Orléans Community Improvement Project Area designations.

items.name: integrity-commissioner-law-no-2021-7.md
items.title: Integrity Commissioner (By-law No. 2021-7) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text establishes the position of Integrity Commissioner, outlining its statutory powers, duties, and functions including acting as Lobbyist Registrar and Meetings Investigator, detailing the appointment process, accountability to Council, access to necessary information, requirements for annual reporting and confidentiality, providing immunity from testimony in civil proceedings, and ensuring indemnity for actions taken in good faith.

items.name: licensing-law-no-2002-189.md
items.title: Licensing (By-law No. 2002-189) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines the requirements and procedures for the licensing, regulation, and governance of various businesses including auctioneers, driving schools, public garages, snow plow contractors, amusement places, all night dance events, food premises, exotic animal entertainment and rescue establishments, adult entertainment establishments, tobacco and vapour product retailers, rickshaws, second-hand goods shops, salvage yards, exhibitions, flea markets, temporary sign lessors, body-rub parlours, itinerant sellers, mobile refreshment vendors, rooming houses, pet shops, private parking enforcement agencies, kennels, and payday loan establishments, detailing application processes, fees, license periods, transfers, inspections, conditions, offences, fines, and license suspension or revocation procedures.

items.name: businesses-regulated-licensing-law-no-2002-189.md
items.title: Businesses Regulated by Licensing (By-law No. 2002-189) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text outlines the licensing requirements, conditions, regulations, insurance, and other rules for various businesses and activities including auctioneers, driving schools, public garages and related automotive services, snow plow contractors, amusement places and events, food premises, exotic animal entertainment and rescue, adult entertainment venues and stores, body-rub parlours, various types of itinerant sellers and mobile vendors, rooming houses, pet shops and kennels, private parking enforcement agencies, and payday loan establishments.

items.name: light-rail-regulatory-monitor-and-compliance-officer-and-lrt-regulation-law-no-2015-301.md
items.title: Light Rail Regulatory Monitor and Compliance Officer and LRT Regulation (By-law No. 2015-301) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text establishes the position of Light Rail Regulatory Monitor and Compliance Officer and defines the regulatory framework for municipal light rail systems, encompassing design, construction, operation, safety, security, rates, and service conditions, with the officer responsible for monitoring compliance and reporting annually.

items.name: lobbyist-registry-law-no-2012-309.md
items.title: Lobbyist Registry (By-law No. 2012-309) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes a lobbyist registry and the role of a Registrar, defining lobbying activities, lobbyists, and public officials, setting registration requirements and exemptions, prohibiting contingency fees, imposing post-employment restrictions, detailing the Registrar's responsibilities for oversight, enforcement, and investigations, including a Code of Conduct for lobbyists, and outlining the process for addressing non-compliance and complaints.

items.name: low-speed-vehicles-law-no-2022-276.md
items.title: Low-Speed Vehicles (By-law No. 2022-276) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The subject is the permission and regulation of low-speed vehicle operation and use, including definitions, requirements for insurance, speed limits, passenger restrictions, towing prohibitions, signage, parking rules, driver licensing, road limitations, intersection usage, vehicle condition and mandatory equipment, an approval process involving plan submission and safety certification, and provisions for enforcement, penalties, and the effective date until June 29, 2027.

items.name: marijuana-grow-operation-remediation-law-no-2012-402.md
items.title: Marijuana Grow Operation Remediation (By-law No. 2012–402) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulations are established for buildings identified as having contained marijuana grow operations, prohibiting their use and requiring owners to conduct inspections and remediation under professional engineer direction, outlining procedures for issuing and serving orders to correct contraventions, enabling enforcement by carrying out required work at the owner's expense with cost recovery through property tax liens, detailing the process for obtaining a certificate of compliance upon satisfactory remediation, specifying applicable fees, and setting out penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: montreal-road-community-improvement-plan-area-law-no-2019-213.md
items.title: Montreal Road Community Improvement Plan Area (By-law No. 2019-213) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Designating a specific area, as shown in Schedule 'A', for community improvement projects.

items.name: municipal-accommodation-tax-law-no-2022-56.md
items.title: Municipal Accommodation Tax (By-law No. 2022-56) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines regulations for a tax on transient accommodation, specifying the rate, which increased from four to five percent effective January 1, 2024, the types of lodging subject to the tax, applicable exemptions, procedures for collection and remittance by providers and designated agents, and provisions for enforcement, audits, assessments, and penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: noise-law-no-2017-255.md
items.title: Noise (By-law No. 2017-255) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text establishes rules governing noise, including restrictions on sound levels and times for activities like operating sound reproduction devices, construction, deliveries, and equipment, while exempting certain actions such as emergency alarms, snow clearing, and agricultural operations, and detailing processes for obtaining special permissions, with enforcement measures and fines for violations.

items.name: notices-and-other-communications-during-postal-service-interruption-law-no-2018-306.md
items.title: Notices and other communications during a postal service interruption (By-law No. 2018-306) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Alternative methods are authorized for sending and receiving official notices and communications during a postal service interruption, permitting personal delivery, leaving at an address, facsimile, email, or newspaper publication for sending, and personal delivery to designated locations or facsimile/email for receiving, excluding notices required by the Official Plan, applicable only while the interruption persists.

items.name: open-air-fire-law-no-2004-163.md
items.title: Open Air Fire (By-law No. 2004-163) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This regulation establishes rules for setting fires in the open air, mandating permits from the Fire Chief with requirements for application and permit holders, detailing conditions for various fire types including campfires, brush fires, burn drums, windrows, and outdoor fireplaces, specifying location restrictions, required distances from structures, permitted materials, and times, outlining exemptions and penalties for non-compliance, defining relevant terms, and superseding previous related rules.

items.name: ottawa-mural-law-no-2022-304.md
items.title: Ottawa Mural (By-law No. 2022-304) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The subject is the regulation of large-scale artworks applied to building walls, establishing definitions for such artworks, requiring permits for their installation and maintenance, detailing the application and review process involving specific panels and representatives, setting standards for content and placement including prohibitions on commercial elements and restrictions on heritage properties, outlining maintenance requirements, and providing for enforcement procedures and penalties for violations.

items.name: over-dimensional-vehicles-city-highways-law-no-2003-497.md
items.title: Over-dimensional Vehicles on City Highways (By-law No. 2003-497) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text regulates the movement of vehicles exceeding standard size or weight limits on highways, requiring permits with different types available based on duration and vehicle characteristics, imposing restrictions on dimensions, weight, timing, and location including specific requirements for a central area and mandating escorts or traffic management plans for larger vehicles, while holding permit holders responsible for any resulting damage.

items.name: parkland-dedication-law-no-2022-280.md
items.title: Parkland Dedication (By-law No. 2022-280) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document sets out regulations requiring the dedication of land or payment of funds for park purposes as a condition of land development or redevelopment, detailing definitions, calculation methods based on development type and density, specific rates and exceptions, procedures for administering collected funds, and transition rules for existing applications.

items.name: parks-and-facilities-law-no-2004-276.md
items.title: Parks and Facilities (By-law No. 2004-276) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulations governing the use and enjoyment of public parks and facilities, including operating hours, permitted and prohibited activities, requirements for permits, property protection, animal control, sports, conduct, enforcement, and penalties.

items.name: permanent-signs-private-property-law-no-2016-326.md
items.title: Permanent Signs on Private Property (By-law No. 2016-326) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulations governing the types, sizes, heights, illumination, placement, permits, fees, maintenance, and enforcement of permanent signs located on private property, including specific rules for designated areas.

items.name: pool-enclosure-law-no-2013-39.md
items.title: Pool Enclosure (By-law No. 2013-39) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulation of enclosures for privately-owned outdoor pools, detailing requirements for construction, maintenance, permits, temporary enclosures, hot tubs, and enforcement.

items.name: private-approach-law-no-2003-447.md
items.title: Private Approach (By-law No. 2003-447) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes rules for creating, changing, locating, designing, maintaining, and removing vehicular access points between private land and public roads, detailing permit procedures, construction standards based on property type, and enforcement measures.

items.name: procedure-law-no-2022-410.md
items.title: Procedure (By-law No. 2022-410) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes the comprehensive rules and procedures governing the proceedings, member conduct, meeting schedules, agenda management, voting, debate, and committee operations for the council and its associated committees and commissions.

items.name: procurement-law-no-2000-50.md
items.title: Procurement (By-law No. 2000-50) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document is a set of regulations governing the procurement of goods, services, and construction, detailing procedures, responsibilities, financial thresholds for various bid methods and non-competitive purchases, contract administration, supplier performance standards, and a process for handling complaints, all aimed at obtaining best value through open, transparent, and fair competition.

items.name: property-maintenance-law-no-2005-208.md
items.title: Property Maintenance (By-law No. 2005-208) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text details regulations for property upkeep, covering the management and removal of refuse and debris, clearing land of heavy undergrowth, long grass, weeds, and dead or damaged plants, maintaining clean yards, ensuring proper drainage, regulating the storage of materials, governing garbage disposal and receptacle placement, requiring maintenance of outdoor furniture, and mandating the removal of snow and ice from roofs and surrounding areas, alongside procedures for enforcement, exceptions for certain activities, and penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: property-standards-law-no-2013-416.md
items.title: Property Standards (By-law No. 2013-416) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes minimum standards for the maintenance, repair, and occupancy of various property types, including residential, non-residential, vacant, open space, and heritage properties, detailing requirements for yards, structures, utilities, safety, cleanliness, pest control, waste disposal, and outlining procedures for enforcement, appeals, and penalties.

items.name: remembrance-day-law-no-2008-355.md
items.title: Remembrance Day (By-law No. 2008-355) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: A regulation requires most retail businesses to remain closed until 12:30 pm on November 11th each year, with specific exceptions for certain types and sizes of establishments like small food stores, pharmacies, gas stations, and others, in recognition of the significance of Remembrance Day.

items.name: rental-housing-property-management-law-no-2020-255.md
items.title: Rental Housing Property Management (By-law No. 2020-255) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document sets out requirements for the management of residential rental properties, mandating that owners of apartment buildings maintain capital maintenance plans, landlords and property managers establish procedures for receiving and responding to tenant service requests within specified timeframes, provide tenants with comprehensive written information covering contact details, service requests, safety, maintenance, waste, and parking, maintain a voluntary registry for tenants requesting assistance, and implement integrated pest management plans including inspections, tenant education, reporting, and treatment protocols, alongside outlining tenant obligations regarding infestations and detailing enforcement provisions and penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: residential-protective-plumbing-law-no-2025-89.md
items.title: Residential Protective Plumbing (By-law No. 2025-89) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Residential property owners can receive financial rebates for installing protective plumbing devices such as backwater valves and sump pumps to reduce basement flooding risk from sewer backups, under a program specifying eligibility criteria, application procedures, required documentation, payment conditions, and maximum rebate amounts.

items.name: right-entry-law-no-2005-326.md
items.title: Right of Entry (By-law No. 2005-326) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The subject is obtaining a permit to authorize entry onto adjoining land for necessary repairs or alterations to buildings, fences, or other structures, detailing the application process, required information, non-refundable permit fee, refundable deposit for potential damage restoration, conditions for entry including providing reasonable notice and restoring the land, the requirement for inspection before permit issuance, and the obligation to compensate for any damage caused during entry.

items.name: right-way-patio-law-no-2023-230.md
items.title: Right of Way Patio (By-law No. 2023-230) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The text establishes regulations for placing and operating patios and parklets in public spaces, detailing permit requirements, application processes, approval criteria, operational standards, seasonal use, insurance, enforcement, penalties, and fees.

items.name: road-activity-law-no-2003-445.md
items.title: Road Activity (By-law No. 2003-445) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document regulates activities on public highways, including road cuts and temporary construction-related encroachments, by establishing requirements for permits, fees, insurance, security, reinstatement, traffic control, and public notice, and outlines procedures for inspection, orders, cost recovery, and penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: sewer-connection-law-no-2003-513.md
items.title: Sewer Connection (By-law No. 2003-513) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document regulates connections to and the use of public and private sewage works, defining terms, outlining the managing authority's duties, setting rules for accessing and altering works, requiring permits for connections and installations, specifying design and construction standards, detailing inspection procedures, defining maintenance responsibilities, addressing blanking and reuse, specifying applicable charges, and outlining offences and penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: sewer-use-law-no-2003-514.md
items.title: Sewer Use (By-law No. 2003-514) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes regulations governing the discharge of matter into sewers and sewage works, defining terms, setting specific requirements and prohibited substances for sanitary, combined, and storm sewers, including concentration and characteristic limits, prohibiting dilution for compliance, regulating the transport and disposal of hauled liquid waste requiring permits and fees, outlining reporting, self-monitoring, and sampling requirements for industrial premises, providing for special discharge agreements and compliance programs under specific conditions, detailing procedures for spills, granting access for inspection and sampling, requiring installation and maintenance of manholes, monitoring devices, interceptors for grease, oil, and sand, and certified amalgam separators for dental practices, prohibiting garbage grinders discharging to sewage works and regulating swimming pool wastewater disposal, assigning liability for damage to the works, and specifying offences and associated penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: shopping-cart-law-no-2013-252.md
items.title: Shopping Cart (By-law No. 2013-252) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: The subject is the regulation of shopping carts, prohibiting their removal from business premises and placement on public areas, requiring owners to implement management systems and label carts, and establishing procedures for the removal, impounding, retrieval, and disposal of carts found in prohibited locations, including provisions for enforcement and penalties within specified regulated areas.

items.name: short-term-borrowing-law-no-2019-268.md
items.title: Short Term Borrowing (By-law No. 2019-268) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Authorization for temporary borrowing of funds to meet current expenditures until revenues are received, subject to limits based on percentages of estimated revenues (50% from January to September, 25% from October to December) up to a maximum of $500 million, with rules for calculating estimates, excluding specific revenue sources like arrears and reserve fund payments, and procedures for loan agreements, execution, providing information to lenders, and repayment upon revenue collection.

items.name: short-term-rental-law-no-2021-104.md
items.title: Short-Term Rental (By-law No. 2021-104) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulations governing short-term rentals establish requirements for hosts, including obtaining permits, adhering to principal residence rules with specific exceptions, maintaining safety standards, providing guest information, and carrying insurance; concurrently, they mandate registration, operational standards, insurance, data provision, and tax collection for property managers and rental platforms, while also outlining procedures for enforcement, penalties, and appeals, and including provisions allowing landlords, condominium corporations, and housing co-operatives to prohibit such rentals.

items.name: signs-city-roads-law-no-2003-520.md
items.title: Signs on City Roads (By-law No. 2003-520) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes comprehensive rules and requirements for the placement, types, and removal of signs and advertising devices situated on public roads, detailing permitted and prohibited signs, general regulations, specific provisions for different sign categories such as accessory, election, event, poster, banner, and wayfinding signs, and outlining enforcement procedures and penalties for non-compliance.

items.name: site-alteration-law-no-2024-448.md
items.title: Site Alteration (By-law No. 2024-448) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text establishes rules for site alteration activities to safeguard agricultural lands and natural features, prevent drainage problems, and avoid public nuisances, outlining requirements for conducting work, maintaining drainage systems, restrictions in protected areas with specific exemptions for activities like normal farming and infrastructure work, and detailing enforcement measures including inspections, orders, penalties, and cost recovery for non-compliance, while also specifying standard practices for sediment control, site protection, and fill material quality.

items.name: site-plan-control-law-no-2014-256.md
items.title: Site Plan Control (By-law No. 2014 - 256) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document outlines a site plan control system designating an area where development requires approval unless exempted based on specific criteria related to building type, size, location, and use, detailing conditions for additions, alterations, replacements, and circumstances where approval is mandatory or can be waived.

items.name: small-business-tax-subclass-law-no-2021-343.md
items.title: Small Business Tax Subclass (By-law No. 2021-343) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Establishing a Small Business Tax Subclass for eligible commercial, industrial, and optional properties based on specific property codes and size criteria, with procedures for inclusion, audits, removal, reconsideration requests, and appeals.

items.name: smoking-and-vaping-law-no-2019-241.md
items.title: Smoking and Vaping (By-law No. 2019-241) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: A regulation prohibits smoking and vaping of tobacco, cannabis, and other substances in designated public and work-related locations including enclosed spaces, outdoor property, patios, and specific venues, placing obligations on those responsible for these areas to prevent violations, remove related items, and display required signage, with penalties for non-compliance and provisions for enforcement.

items.name: solid-waste-services-law-no-2024-453.md
items.title: Solid Waste Services (By-law No. 2024 - 453) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes comprehensive regulations governing solid waste management services, including collection rules for residential, commercial, and institutional properties, specifications for waste types, containers, and set-out procedures, requirements for utilizing a designated waste facility, applicable fees for services and disposal, and provisions for administering and enforcing these waste management standards.

items.name: special-events-city-streets-law-no-2001-260.md
items.title: Special Events on City Streets (By-law No. 2001-260) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulating special events on public streets through a permit system that includes application requirements, approval procedures with conditions and appeals, rules for participant conduct and safety, and provisions for enforcement and penalties.

items.name: special-events-public-and-private-property-law-no-2013-232.md
items.title: Special Events on Public and Private Property (By-law No. 2013-232) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text establishes regulations for special events on public and private property, covering the process for obtaining permits, conditions for holding events, exemptions, fees for required services such as emergency and traffic management, procedures for appeals and permit changes, requirements for insurance and indemnity, general rules of conduct, inspection authority, organizer responsibilities, penalties for violations, and specific rules for beach events, including detailed schedules for service charges.

items.name: temporary-signs-private-property-law-no-2004-239.md
items.title: Temporary Signs on Private Property (By-law No. 2004-239) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Temporary signs on private property are governed by rules specifying where they can be placed to avoid hazards, requiring permits for some types but exempting others like election or real estate signs, with restrictions on size, height, duration, and location, and provisions for removal and associated fees.

items.name: traffic-and-parking-law-no-2017-301.md
items.title: Traffic and Parking (By-law No. 2017-301) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Rules governing traffic and parking on highways, covering regulations for signs, stopping and parking, zones, traffic movement, speed limits, heavy vehicles, driving, pedestrians, bicycles, penalties, administration, and specific parking rules for private and public property, persons with disabilities, and municipal lots, along with procedures for reporting related issues.

items.name: transit-law-no-2007-268.md
items.title: Transit (By-law No. 2007-268) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes the regulations for the public transportation system, covering definitions, rules for passenger conduct and fare payment, requirements for using transit facilities and vehicles, rules for vehicle operation on dedicated transit routes, and provisions for enforcement.

items.name: tree-protection-law-no-2020-340.md
items.title: Tree Protection (By-law No. 2020-340) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes regulations for protecting municipal trees and municipal natural areas, and trees on private property in urban areas, requiring permits for their injury or destruction under certain circumstances, and detailing associated protection measures, reporting requirements, compensation for removed trees, exemptions, and enforcement procedures.

items.name: use-and-care-roads-law-no-2003-498.md
items.title: Use and Care of Roads (By-law No. 2003-498) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This text establishes regulations for the use and care of public roads and associated areas like boulevards and sidewalks, detailing general prohibited activities, outlining specific conditions and requirements for permitted uses such as boulevard gardens, free library boxes, and temporary retail displays, setting rules for maintenance, cleaning, repair, temporary closures, and protecting infrastructure, defining enforcement authority, penalties for contravention, and listing prohibited plant species within the right of way.

items.name: vacant-property-law-no-2022-197.md
items.title: Vacant Property (By-law No. 2022-197) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulation and permitting of vacant buildings and vacant lands, including requirements for obtaining and maintaining permits, owner responsibilities, insurance requirements, enforcement procedures, penalties for non-compliance, and processes for permit refusal, suspension, revocation, and appeal.

items.name: vacant-unit-tax-law-no-2022-135.md
items.title: Vacant Unit Tax (By-law No. 2022-135) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Regulations are established for taxing residential properties deemed vacant, defined primarily by being unoccupied for over 184 days in the prior year and not serving as a principal residence or long-term rental, requiring owners to declare property status annually, setting tax rates as a percentage of assessed value that increase with consecutive vacancy, providing exemptions for specific circumstances like renovations, medical needs, or recent sales, outlining administrative procedures for declarations, evidence requests, and inspections, detailing penalties for late or false declarations including deemed vacancy, and establishing processes for owners to dispute the tax and for audits to ensure compliance.

items.name: vehicle-hire-law-no-2016-272.md
items.title: Vehicle For Hire (By-law No. 2016-272) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document establishes rules for the licensing, regulation, and governance of vehicles for hire, encompassing taxicabs, taxicab drivers, taxicab plate holders, and taxicab brokers, as well as limousine services and Private Transportation Companies including their drivers and vehicles, detailing requirements for licensing, operation, vehicle standards, insurance, inspections, transfers, and enforcement procedures.

items.name: voluntary-admail-reduction-program-law-no-2003-493.md
items.title: Voluntary Admail Reduction Program (By-law No. 2003-493) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: A program establishes a voluntary system where property owners or occupants can opt-out of receiving unaddressed advertising material by purchasing and displaying a sticker, which prohibits distributors from delivering such material, although exceptions apply for paid newspapers, community newspapers, election campaign material, and government circulars, and specific rules govern delivery locations and times for properties without the sticker.

items.name: ward-boundaries-and-council-composition-law-no-2021-3.md
items.title: Ward Boundaries and Council Composition (By-law No. 2021-3) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document consolidates regulations establishing ward boundaries and council composition, detailing the division into 24 wards each electing one member, plus a mayor, effective for the 2022 municipal elections and subsequent terms, incorporating modifications resulting from a tribunal order and future amendments.

items.name: ward-boundaries-wards-6-9-11-13-21-24-law-no-2025-5.md
items.title: Ward Boundaries of Wards 6, 9, 11, 13, 21, 24 (By-law No. 2025-5) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Establishing amendments to the boundaries for Wards 6, 9, 11, 13, 21, and 24, modifying a previous boundary establishment based on attached schedules, effective November 15, 2026.

items.name: water-law-no-2019-74.md
items.title: Water (By-law No. 2019-74) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: This document regulates the municipal water supply system, detailing its operation, maintenance, and extension, assigning responsibilities for system management, property owner duties including private service, backflow prevention, and access, establishing requirements for permits, inspections, and service connections, setting rules for water metering, billing, water, wastewater, and fire supply rates, frontage charges, and other fees, outlining procedures for service interruptions, hydrant use, and water conservation, including provisions for mandatory and optional connections to the system and well management in specific areas, and defining enforcement measures and penalties for violations.

items.name: zoning-law-no-2008-250.md
items.title: Zoning (By-law No. 2008-250) | City of Ottawa
items.summary: Understanding and applying land use regulations involves interpreting zone codes structured with primary zones, subzones, suffixes, schedules, and exceptions, recognizing that provincial orders can override local rules, knowing how the official compilation is updated to show enacted and pending changes, applying the more restrictive rule during amendment transitions, seeking information from designated officers, and understanding existing rights for non-conforming uses and non-complying structures.
